newsitem.title: ITALY: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Friday April 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Friday April 11.

text.p: The following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* Prime minister Romano Prodi comfortably survived a vote of confidence called in the Senate after his hard left Communist Refoundation allies broke ranks and defied the government on a security force for Albania. The centre-left government won the vote by 162 votes to 81 with one abstention, Prodi said he was confident his government would also win the Chamber of Deputies' approval (all).

* Democratic Party of the Left (PDS) leader Massimo D'Alema harshly criticised Prodi's address to the Senate, calling it a shame the way the prime minister tried not to oppose Communist Refoundation's claims. Foreign minister Lamberto Dini was also not satisfied with Prodi's weak attitude towards his hard-left ally (all).

* A report by national statistics institute ISTAT showed Italy had a 3.089 trillion lire trade surplus with non-European countries in February. ISTAT also said that Italy had a global trade surplus in January of 1.655 trillion lire against a surplus of 135 billion lire in January 1996 (all).
* The Ministry of Transport said new car registrations rose 25.04 percent to 220,500 units in March compared with 176,348 in March 1996 (all).
* Carmaker Fiat saw a rise of 22.7 percent in its group March new car registration to 96,020 vehicles from 78,278 in March 1996 (all).

* The board of Monte Paschi di Siena said it had approved the purchase of a three percent stake in Istituto Bancario San Paolo, thus becoming part of a hard-core of shareholders in the Turin-based bank due to be privatised later this year (all).

* Rainer Masera, director general of investment bank IMI, said the group, which currently holds a two percent stake in San Paolo, is very likely to exercise the option to raise its stake to five percent and thereby become of a hard core of allies in San Paolo (Il Sole 24 Ore).
* Information technology group Olivetti fell 6 percent on the Milan bourse on press reports of losses of over 50 billion lire at its Telemedia company (all).
* Net yields of three, six and twelve-month short-term Treasury bills (BOTs) fell below 6 percent, the lowest level in the last twenty years (all).
Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
